description:
I was walking around here, uncertain what to eat and looking for a quick bite to eat that isn't too expensive and just stumbled into this restaurant.

Let me say, their roast pork sandwich is legit on point.  It's spicy with jalepineo and sweet mayo.  Bread is crunchy in the outside but not so tough you can't take a nice big bite, toasted right.

The sandwich may appear small at first, but it's heavy in your hand, because they have THICC slides of toast pork.  They keep on bits of fat at the slides that make it juicy af.  Definitely flavorful and not dry that some banh mi places (ya know that old red meat)

What makes this sandwich 5/5 is that they even marinate the carrots so that it's a bit sweet and still crunchy.   It's the little details on the sandwich that rounds it out.

It's a tiny hidden little place but definitely one of those corner joints you keep coming back again and again.  Also it's ran by a nice  Vietnamese family.  20% tip for sure.
author: Allen S.

description:
Vegan lunchtime options in Hayes Valley are few and far between, especially when I need something quick, healthy and fresh. DragonEats is my go-to for lunch! 

I usually order the teriyaki tofu fresh rolls and they're totally satisfying. I feel nourished and am usually good until dinner time! Best part: they're only $7.60. It get packed during the lunch hour but service is quick and super friendly.

Highly recommended!
author: Angela H.

description:
I thought this place was pretty solid, and honestly the best place to go for the price! With lunch being less than $10 a person, I'd say this place is great to get food that isn't overpriced in the city. My sister and I came here on a Wednesday right before noon, and there were a few seats open and 2 tables for 2 also free. Several people stop here for a quick bite to eat or order to go and eat elsewhere (everything is packaged in to-go containers anyway). Service is straightforward and friendly.

We got:
1) 5 spice chicken banh mi: it was pretty good! We both like the flavor of the chicken, but which the bread was a little softer like the typical french torpedo baguettes usually used (if you're not careful biting into your sandwich, you'll definitely have a cut up mouth/gums)
2) Roasted pork bowl: we actually enjoyed that this bowl had less noodles than the typical Vietnamese place that would have majority of the dish be noodles. Instead, there was a lot of shredded carrots, pickled celery, and other greens. Inside the bowl is a small container of sweetened fish sauce to pour over your bowl. Although it wasn't truly authentic (imo) to what a vermicelli noodle bowl is, it definitely had some of the same flavors and was reminiscent to it. I'd come back. 
3) Viet iced coffee: you can't go wrong with this--although I think $4 is a little steep in price.

Overall, it's a fast, affordable lunch spot that people should check out if they want some Vietnamese food!
author: Shannon N.

description: My favorite item here is the soup!! It's only about ~$3 and tastes amazing!! It has a little bit of kale and a really great pickled/sour vegetable flavor (I know that probably doesn't sound appetizing but I don't know how else to describe it and that's how it translates from Mandarin). I usually order the soup + shrimp roll together here. I haven't tried the sandwiches but those look really great too!
author: Jeanette S.

description:
When needing a quick bite, I always go for a banh mi! 

Parking: Paid street parking 

Ambience: Modern with mismatched dining tables / chairs. Great setting for a quick bite or for eating alone. 

Service: The staff was friendly; however, there was not too much interaction beyond ordering. 

Order: Roasted Pork Banh Mi: This sandwich was extremely fatty for me, both in flavor and the meat itself. I didn't like that b/c it seemed to drench the sandwich, making it hard for me to taste the freshness of the vegetables. While I would not say it's a bad banh mi, I was disappointed at how fatty it was. 

Verdict: 3. The ambience and price point is great for those looking for a quick bite; however, I would not eat this sandwich again b/c of how fatty it was.
author: Michelle B.

description:
Always love myself a good banh mi. Dropped by here right after the pride parade since all that walking had me really hungry.

The service was friendly, and was really just there for ordering. Got a pork meatball banh mi. It was pretty good in comparison to a lot of other banh mi locations I've been too. My only really knock on this was the size of the banh mi for the price point. It was of traditional size, however it was pretty expensive for it being $6.75. In Vietnam itself, it would go for around a dollar or two, but back in Virginia, for $6.75 you could something about 2-2.5x the size of this one.

Overall was a good banh mi, but the pricing or portion could be better.
author: Timothy D.

description:
I didn't know this was a chain of three, none of them open in the evening when I had a better chance of hitting them for a banh mi. Alas, I was strolling in Hayes Valley late one afternoon for a change and in the mood for a nosh that I'm sure I was convincing myself would be an early dinner. It was, trust me. Anyway, I've walked by this spot numerous times but didn't know it was such a small and popular space. I was relieved to see on the overhead menu not only banh mis (seven of them - photo: http://bit.ly/2rKDdMC) but also fresh bowls, fresh rolls, and green salads. Thank goodness as I'm off bread for now.

Now my conscience was telling me to order a green salad, but some rice noodles wouldn't kill me, would it? WOULD IT? Anyway, I ordered the $7.25 Five-Spice Chicken Fresh Bowl, which had shredded carrots, cilantro, pickled daikon, roasted peanuts, and crispy shallots mixed with rice noodles and iceberg lettuce in a deep cardboard container (photo: http://bit.ly/2KZrum1). It was pretty tasty, and despite the awkward vessel it was all put in, the quantity was satisfying for a meal. If they stayed open for a couple more hours, I'd come back here more often. I also think the cheap-seat theater crowd would agree with me.

FOOD - 4 stars...a solidly satisfying bowl of Vietnamese goodness 
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...compact with seating more likely at the counter
SERVICE - 3 stars...hardly a word was exchanged 
TOTAL - 4 stars...an 8PM closing time would be nice
author: Ed U.

description:
I was extremely disappointed when I realized that there's absolutely nothing for me to eat in this area on my lunch until I found DragonEats!

Don't be discouraged by all of the people sitting and waiting inside, I've never waited more than 7 mins for my food ordered at the counter.

I stick with the roasted pork fresh bowl (sin cilantro) because it's delicious.
The pork is moist, warm, and they give you just enough fish sauce to add into your bowl. I prefer a container or sriracha on mine as well, but you do you.
The bahn mi is also great, but it takes more hands to eat that, which I don't have enough of during my working lunches.

I'd like to try the 5 spice chicken that everyone raves about, but there are some asian spices I DO NOT like and i'm afraid to ruin a good go-to lunch spot for me, so I may not venture out to try that.

It's about $8 for lunch and definitely doable when you don't have a lunch prepared for your work day.
I try (or maybe don't really) not to come here at least once a week, but hey we can't all be great at everything!
author: Connie T.

description: Great place to stop by and grab good Vietnamese food. Affordable and the atmosphere is great. Would recommend to anyone just wandering the streets and need a bite to eat.
author: Cameron M.

description:
I love DragonEats! It's under $10 lunch that's filled with fresh ingredients. It's a little pricier than say Saigon Sandwich but like I mentioned the ingredients taste fresher.

The line is always relatively short and there's some seating but I usually just get it to go. The interior is nice decor/ambiance. Staff is always great too.
author: Mimi T.

description: Always great, always fast, and always friendly service. We live around the corner and go weekly.
author: Matt B.

description: Affordable, tasty, and made quick. DragonEats is my goto lunch spot. Even if the line is long you'll have your food within 10-15 minutes, if it's short you won't have to wait more than 5. The sandwiches are consistently great. The bread is crispy but not hard, all of the meat options are great, the sauce and peppers add a nice kick, and there's always enough veggies (carrots especially) to cool it down. I recommend the 5 spice chicken or the duck.
author: Alex G.

description: Tasty sandwiches - flavorful meat (we tried the garlic chicken and pork) crunchy bread, packed full of pickled veggies and herbs. Washed it down with a Vietnamese coffee as well, kept me alert for the remainder of the TED conference
author: Naomi A.

description: I always came here after work for their delicious and generously sized banh mis! Too good!
author: Christina C.

description:
Old Asian lady walks in leading a party of four. She walks up to the counter and orders four Banh Mi, pays, and steps aside. Her party all order individually, a couple of others ordering two or more.

They take their seat and go to town.

Five-spice Chicken
Roast Pork
Side of chips

Five Stars!
author: James G.

description:
Delicious banh mi sandwiches & vermicelli bowls for around $7. Given the location in Hayes Valley, it's a pretty good deal and tastes very fresh!

The setup is along the likes of a hole in the wall. The shop is pretty small, there's stool seating and random tables to sit at and I imagine most people do take out here.

They serve sandwiches and bowls with protein such as 5 spice chicken (recommend!), BBQ pork, duck and tofu teriyaki. The sandwiches come a bit on the smaller end but they are filling and the baguette is very fresh and crispy!

My main criticism is that the vermicelli bowls could be filled up all the way since it's only halfway through the cup they serve you in. 

Overall great place to stop by for a tasty banh mi!
author: Chelsea W.

description:
One of the better Banh Mi sandwiches I've had so far. The tofu ones often tend to be a bit bland and dry but the teriyaki sauce they marinate to tofu with here makes them very juicy and flavorful. The bread is fresh with a crispy crust and they're also a little bit spicy, which is great. 
Service is fast and friendly and the interior looks hip and super clean. There is free cucumber water and the prices are not bad either (7 something for most items). Definitely going back to try their bowls, salads, and Vietnamese coffee as well!
author: Steven M.

description:
Food: 5/5
Space: 4/5
Service: 5/5

Favorite Banh Mi in the area by far -- good, affordable, and consistent. I always go with the Five-Spice Chicken. Not a ton of room to sit-down and chat, though the decor inside is sort of random but charming. I generally walk my Banh Mi over to Patricia's Green and eat outside. Service is always quick and friendly and the line moves quickly.
author: Derrick F.

description: Do you know what is truly great about Banh MI sandwiches?  It almost doesn't matter what's in them because they are bound to be awesome.  Yesterday's stop at DragonEats was due to my feeling peckish and looking for something satisfying after a long day of sightseeing along Pier 39.  DragonEats must be a regular stop for locals in the area because these sandwiches are delicious and the bread is crunchy and don't even get me started on the soup!  I ordered the pork Banh Mi with soup and homemade lemonade - all very well-seasoned.  The cucumber, carrots, and meat of the sandwich were delicious.  They were out of duck during my visit, which can only speak to its popularity.  The soup with was full of Kale (superfood!) and had a lemon peppery kick to it.  Take that airborne germs!  This small sandwich shop is definitely worth a stop in for pick-up.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Fast, fresh, delicious food ! 
There is a line at rush our but they tend to move through very quickly !
author: Dorin C.

description: First I order a garlic butter chicken sandwich with roasted pork. That was dismantled in 5 minutes. I went and got another sandwich but, just the roasted pork. Sandwich is dummy smackin and crackin. Found it on yelp and will be coming back fa sho! Props to the Asian homie who plugged it.
author: Pablo J.

description: They were out of duck so our plan B was sardine...  Delicious!!!   I'm glad they were out of duck!   The bread is perfect,  vegetables fresh and crunchy... Slight hint of sesame oil... Not too sweet.   I would've liked a hotter chile but,  oh well.   Definitely going back.
author: Bleep S.

description:
I happened to be early to a conference, so I wanted a quick bite to eat and was happily surprised. This is probably an example of that perfect go to mom and pop restaurant with the perfect meal every single time you go. 

I would definitely come again to try the other banh my because the 5 spice chicken was delicious! It was affordable and delicious!
author: Jessica Z.

description:
Great little lunch place for quick Vietnamese sandwiches, bowls and salads.  Cheap, tasty and relatively heathy.  Gets busy but still in and out in under 10 minutes.

Great teriyaki tofu fresh bowls!
author: Ryder M.

description: It's a small, nondescript Vietnamese restaurant where you order food and drinks at the counter.  I ordered the $7.00 Roast Pork Bowl with Vermicelli Noodles and $3.75 Iced Vietnamese Coffee.  The bowl was small but flavorful - perfectly-sized for a light meal.  And, the coffee was a bit stronger than I prefer but tasty nonetheless.  This isn't a place where you'd linger with friends.  There are about 14 or so chairs with window seating and a few small tables.
author: Aileen M.

description:
I enjoy coming here to buy my lunch because it is really close by my work place . It is a small shop and there are several tables . I like the bowl with pho . My favorite one is the tofu because I like the teriyaki sauce and it was yummy . 
The guy was nice and super friendly
author: Isabelle L.

description:
Came to the neighborhood to run an errand, and wanted to grab a quick bite to eat. Found this place, and decided to give it a try. Very affordable and quick. Sandwich was fresh and delicious.

Would come back, but probably wouldn't come out of my way to go here because parking is difficult.
author: Jessica S.

description: Yummy, fair priced, and quick. Interior is so-so, but I rarely dine in. $7 for a sandwich is a good deal for SF. I just wish it was open a tad later than 6pm
author: Rachel R.

description:
I used to go here all the time when I worked near city hall. I love how healthy and well presented the food here is, and that dishes are heavy on the veges and meat or tofu versus too much noodles. And the spring rolls are delicious, I wish I lived closer to this place.

The Vietnamese iced coffee is pretty darn tasty, though if you're watching your sugar intake you might want to refrain, it's more like a tasty dessert!
author: Annie K.

description:
On average, very solid, but DO NOT order the duck banh mi. We tried the pork, garlic butter chicken, and the duck, and the worst one, by far, was the duck banh mi. There was very little meat, and mostly fat, and they don't include the pickled carrots and daikon with the duck. 

On the other hand, the pork banh mi and the garlic butter chicken banh mi were both excellent. The ratios of meat to vegetables were very well balanced, and the bread wasn't too crunchy or too soft, but just right. Who am I, Goldilocks? Anyways, the garlic butter chicken was definitely the star of the show in my opinion, which is strange, because I traditionally prefer pork. But the chicken breast was very moist, and and just went really well with the peppers and sliced pickled vegetables. 

At around $7 each, they can be considered expensive, given that Saigon Sandwich is just a few blocks away with their $4 banh mi, but I'd say you get a little more attention to detail at DragonEats. I've had my order messed up 9 times out of 10 at Saigon Sandwich, whereas DragonEats definitely pays more attention. People behind the counter were very friendly, and the two ladies making the food in the back were very meticulous, even though they were probably a bit slower than you'd expect.

Will definitely be back if I'm craving that garlic butter chicken banh mi. Will have to give their other dishes and sandwiches a try too, when I'm in the area.
author: Eric J.

description: Great food.  The roasted pork bahn mi was full of lots of flavors.  Very reasonably priced.  Only had to wait a few minutes to get my food. I'm io
author: Robert S.

description: Not bad flavor wise. Ordered 5 spice chicken banh mi and a pork bowl. For the $7-8 price tag, it's a little skimpy. There's a shop with more authentic flavors and bigger portions a few blocks away for half the price.
author: Foodie F.

description:
On New Year's Eve afternoon (12/31/2016), I arrived in San Francisco until I discovered this place after I bookmarked this page on my Yelp app for a while. "DragonEats" serves the customers to taste their Vietnamese sandwiches and entrees in a fusion American twist! The atmosphere is much laid back and elegant as I welcomed there. The concept is much like an Asian Fusion method by mixing traditional and contemporary combined.

The employees here are doing a great job for making the customers like me an incredible service! Friendly and approachable. No cons at all!

Now onto the food! Since it was on the middle of lunch and snack in between, I ordered their signature banh mi called, 5 Spices Chicken. As I ate it, it tasted very good and delicious! It has well balanced flavors for the chicken and natural ingredients together although the cooked chicken breasts pieces are closely bland to me despite it lacked the half of the spices of the chicken. Hopefully, the spices for the chicken will improve it's natural flavors in the future. Otherwise, what a good snackie lunch meal!

Parking at DragonEats can be challenging to park. You can park at the nearby surface street parking or parking garage if it's available. Alternatively, you can also ride a bike, walk, carpool or public transportation easier without the hassles and gimmicks.

In the end, DragonEats is the finest and most remarkable local Vietnamese Fusion banh mi shop that I've ever visited for the first time. Perfect for friends, family and co-workers gatherings. A well visit. My rating: 3 1/2 stars.
author: William L.

description:
There is a large selection of banh mi sandwiches here with a variety of different meats. All sandwiches priced at or under $7 and are about the size of a water bottle. It looks a bit small at first but they stuff it with a very generous amount of meat so in reality the sandwiches are a great deal.  I was pretty full after just half a sandwich. 
They also do vermicelli bowls and salads!
We got the roasted pork banh mi and the garlic butter chicken banh mi. Both were in a toasted mini baguette with pickled carrots, cilantro, jalapeño among other things. The roasted pork was in slices. It was flavorful but a bit dry, so it relied a lot on the bits of pork fat on each slice. Yummy but not that healthy I would imagine. The garlics butter chicken came in the form of slow cooked shredded chicken. It was tender and rich in flavor. This was my favorite. 
I came here for lunch on a Sunday afternoon and it was either full nor empty. There is a good amount of sitting space and a pleasantly paced stream of people coming in and out which made this Dragoneats a great place to sit down for a slow casual lunch.
Overall, good casual food at good value. I would come here again if I were craving Vietnamese food.
author: Amy X.

description:
This place is awesome, always stop by here when I am in town. The banh mi is delicious. I don't even eat them usually but once I tried this place, it's the only
place I go because they just don't make them like this anywhere else. 

The location is nice a cozy. Pretty sweet place to chill and have a viet coffee, catch up with a friend or do some work on a laptop. 

Food comes out fast, the people are nice, overall just a great spot with great food.
author: T M.

description:
I would never pay $6.50 for a regular Banh Mi unless it's at DragonEats. I've grown up around delicious homemade banh mi my whole life and know when good ingredients are used. I've tried both locations (Folsom and Gough) and both have been super consistent in service and taste. I have noticed that the Folsom location charges $.25 more for the soup, but it's totally okay because it comes in a rather big bowl. 

I've had the shrimp papaya here which is super good with a ton of sriracha. The pork banh mis here are also a must try if you're into a fattier meat in a toasted baguette. Every time I've come they've had their soup of the day as the chicken broth with leafy greens that seriously cured my cold and made me feel 100% better after the meal. 

I would come here again and again. It's really nice to hear Vietnamese chatter in the back from the workers as well. Keep up the good work!
author: My N.

description:
Such a gem of a place! Love everything they serve, love the prices and friendly family vibe! It's one of my absolute favorite spots.

It's rare to find a casual spot in Hayes Valley that is not exorbitant and a little pretentious but this spot is the absolute antithesis of that. It feels light and airy but also intimate on the inside (it's a small spot about 500 sq ft of eating space) and though it's always busy I always find a seat or a stool to sit and enjoy my meal. People eat quickly and leave so there is never too long of a wait for an open seat. 

Now the food! I almost always get their Banh My although I've had their soups and love those too. I've tried all the Banh My but my absolute favorite is the 5 Spice Chicken!The ingredients are fresh, the taste is super authentic and the bread is toasty and soft, it's some of the best I've ever had!! If you are a Banh My fan you will for sure not be disappointed. I thought Turtle Tower in the TL had the best Bahn My in the city but I think these guys nail it and have my vote!! 

They are only open for lunch so get there early and thank me later
author: Grace L.

description: Fast service, nice staff and amazing bahn mi sandwiches! The pork bahn mi (no pate) and the shrimp spring rolls are my go to! I usually call in my order and it's ready in 10 minutes so I never have to wait when I pick it up.
author: Heather C.

description: Soooo good.  The best BanMi salad I have had in a long time.   Small spot with quick friendly service.
author: Brandie B.

description: Prices are good and the service is very quick. They were out of roasted duck so I got the roasted pork banh mi, which was pretty good.
author: Aditi S.

description: I eat here almost every day. Fantastic food, friendly service, affordable prices. I always get the garlic butter chicken bahn mi and a chicken salad. Love this place.
author: Sam S.

description: Went here for lunch while in SF. Place is a hole in the wall and quite small. They have some stools if you want to eat in but not the most spacious place. I came in on the early side and there was no line. Ordered a five spice chicken banh mi sandwich which I really enjoyed. Ingredients were fresh especially the carrots and peppers and cilantro. Got some chips to go with it. Definitely worthwhile and I would go back. By noon or so line had built up and there was a bit of a wait.
author: Erin O.

description: Quick and the fresh bowls are great.  Probably need to expand my menu but so far really happy. Service is great!
author: Sandy N.

description: Delicious!! Super fast service and really good value especially for SF. Pork is on point and super authentic and fresh. The chicken bowl was also really flavorful.
author: Abigail S.

description: Great food. Great price. Happened to have a craving for banh mi sandwiches and this was the perfect location. I'll be coming back again.
author: Jay M.

description: My go to lunch spot. Really fresh and tasty ingredients. I always get their side of chicken ginger broth soup with kale in addition to my order. Great affordable price if you are looking to pay less than $10 for lunch in the city.
author: Marvelous M.

description:
It was alright. I'd want to give it 3.5 stars 

Ordered the duck bahn mi. The duck was flavorful and quite saucy. However, the sandwich was lacking in filling and other toppings. Compared to traditional bahn mis, there were scarce fillers like vegetable slices etc. I felt like I was eating duck and bread. Granted I did appreciate the toasted bun. 

Not authentic Vietnamese bahn mi but still a flavorful sandwich. Cheap for the area, good service, get you in and out quickly, and surrounded by a lot of boutique shops in the Hayes Valley area
author: Carissa G.

description: The service here is incredible, and so are the sandwiches. We came in at lunch time, ordered, and within 4 minutes, we were eating. The Bahn MI's are reasonably priced for being in the city, and there was a wide selection. I ordered the grilled pork, and wanted 5 more!! This place is extremely efficient, a fun environment to be in, conveniently located right in the middle of Hayes Valley, and should not be avoided! I will be back!!
author: Ross S.

description: Ooooooh Mmmmm Gggggg!!! So good. Ok, so were in SFO, and I really wanted some Thai food, but it was too early for dinner so we needed something to hold us over. My bf said, let's get a Vietnamese Sandwich!! I was like...ugh....I don't want a sandwich....but he was like...trust me....and I was like uhhh okay....We got there and it was cute little place and the food smelled amazing. I was like...hmmm...I'm interested in the sandwich because this place smells sooo good. Well, we looked at the menu and the prices were great! We couldn't decide between the chicken, pork, or duck. We decided on chicken and split it. We got our sandwiches and unwrapped them and they looked and smelled beautiful!! I know beautiful is a funny description, but they looked so fresh yet, they were a hot sandwich. Next I took a bite and fell in love!! Omg, this sandwich was so flavorful and different and fresh and I was like ...where has this been all of my life!!! It was so good that we ordered another one but the pork one and it was so delicious too. The second time around I asked for extra sauce because that sauce was out of this world!!! I was stuffed afterwards, but it was worth it! The owners (I think) /people working there were so kind and generous. This place was a little far from where I was staying, but I will pay $12.00 for Uber to get this sandwich next time I'm in SFO!!!! Thanks guys!!!
author: Christa R.

description:
Maybe the prices here are just a tad steep given the portion sizes, but you can't deny that these are seriously delicious, good-quality banh mi sandwiches.

The garlic butter chicken, for example, was delightfully delicious, juicy, and savory, with a good balance of vegetables and a nicely crunchy (but not too much so) baguette providing a solid base. Their spring rolls, while also pricely, are similarly fulfilling.

Service is also fast and friendly here. I only wish they were open later, so as to provide another option for a cheap pre-concert meal or a nice, compact takeout dinner. Thanks to Yelp for another good find!
author: Vincent L.

description:
I consider myself a 'spring roll aficionado' they are my go to order at any Vietnamese place.  I love the combo of Tofu, fresh veggies and that smooth peanut sauce mmm.  So, recently I had a craving and was in the Hayes Valley area.  Typically, I go to some spots near me in "Little Saigon" aka the Tenderloin, but I was starving and found Dragon Eats after a quick yelp search.

This spot is located right in the Hayes Valley and is actually pretty nondescript.  There is no sign outside, only the menu posted on the window.  Walking in, the spot is fairly small, about three tables and then stools lining the windows to sit up on the ledge.  I ordered the Tofu spring rolls ($6.50. 2 per order).  I assume these were pre-made because by the time I helped myself to some of the complementary cucumber water they were already up and ready.  

The spring rolls were fairly disappointing.  As mentioned, I think they were pre-made and were a bit warm/room temperature which ruined the texture.  The peanut sauce was quite delicious, however because the rolls came pre-cut also (into thirds) they all just fell apart when I was eating them.  The flavors were good, but just a bit hard to eat with the warmish temperature and stuff falling out everywhere.  Also, inside the place was a damn sauna.  Seriously, it is small but the windows were even fogging up it was so warm in here (thank goodness for that refreshing complementary cucumber water). Possibly I would try the Banh Mi next time as I do appreciate that they offer veg options but wouldn't go for the spring rolls again.
author: Kelsey B.

description: Always a favorite quick lunch spot. I always get the pork or duck banh mi and either lemonade or iced coffee. There's a fair amount of meat in each banh mi and the veggies are fresh. I wish the bun was softer since the bun really makes a good banh mi. That's the only thing stopping it from five stars
author: Jin N.

description: My favorite place to grab a bite during my lunch break. Delicious sandwiches and bowls for a really great price. The food and ingredients are always fresh. Highly recommend the pork!
author: Sarah N.

description: I'm so glad I've found this place! I love Vietnamese sandwiches and am so glad it's close to my house. I've tried a few of the sandwiches and haven't been disappointed.
author: Katlyn H.

description: I was surprised at how cheap this place was! You get a whole meal for under $10 which as we all know is unheard of in SF. I recommend the chicken sandwich but maybe hold the jalapeños because these ones were the hottest ones I've ever tried. Very good restaurant though and VERY fast.
author: Daniel C.

description:
Dragon eats sounds like they're serving you what the mythical creature noms on. Instead, they give you Vietnamese delights. Banh mi sandwiches and cold noodle dishes with 5 spiced protein of your choosing. 

I didn't feel like eating a sandwich so went with the noodles and it turned out to be a good decision.  The portions aren't huge but it's lunch and under 10 dollars so it met my expectations. I do wish they would turn up the heat on the fish sauce that use you on the noodles. The one they provide is a little sweet for my tastebuds but nothing a little Sriracha can't fix. My lunch buddy also seemed to enjoy the classic bbq pork banh mi. I saw others ordering that in droves as well so it must be a popular item.

Seating is limited but if you're looking to grab and go, you could do much worse for the area.
author: Quoc N.

description: Amazing hole-in-the-walk place in Hayes! I've had the fresh shrimp rolls and 5-spice chicken bahn-mi, and both were delicious. There's very little sit down space, but the food comes out within minutes so you can easily pop by for a pick up. Best part is the price -- super affordable, especially when compared to other lunch options on Hayes (I'm looking at you Souvla). So if you'd rather skip the line and eat at half the price, I'd highly suggest coming here instead!
author: Christine H.

description:
Once long ago when they only accepted cash, 
my son forgot to bring cash and since he's been coming here a lot, they told him to pay the next visit. 
Who does that anymore? He's a loyal customer now. 

One of the affordable eateries in Hayes Valley. 
They are super friendly staff and the food comes out quickly. My favorite is the Tofu Bowl. Give them a try. 
I bring everyone here.
author: Julie K.

description:
Perfect little eatery in Hayes Valley. Reasonably priced Bahn mi sandwiches and noodles. We had the 5 spice chicken noodle bowl and the roasted pork bahn mi. Both were tasty and the bread on the bahn mi was fresh! Service was perfect and they played the best music (once soundtrack, train, etc.) 
Decor is cute- counter height tables for the most part but some tables as well.
I'll be back!
author: Semuteh F.

description: If you've got a hankering for Vietnamese food, especially a Banh Mi and I mean a real Vietnamese Banh Mi, you need to check this place out. The food is amazeballs, the iced coffee is heaven and the service is so efficient and friendly. If you want to sit down and eat, you can and enjoy your food and some people watching or you can take it to go. I highly recommend you eat here at least once while visiting San Francisco.
author: Monmanee N.

description: Well the price is right. Due to Thanxgiving tomorrow they have no PORK... waaaah. So we chose Duck and chicken Bahn Mi with fresh shrimp roll. The fresh rolls were very nice with the red cabbage inside and added such a brush of color! It was pretty tasty. Everyone that walked in wanted Pork tho. That was funny. No hot tea either and it's cold out. Oh well water it is!
author: Rene D.

description:
Pros: incredibly cheap for SF, very tasty and fast, cute and not overly cramped location, free candy

Cons: portion slightly too small to be a full meal
author: Cobi A.

description: Great, flavorful food, and extremely quick service (our two orders came out in just minutes). Would recommend
author: Rahul M.

description:
A Banh Mi for over $6??? You've got to be kidding me! Growing up in Oakland, I always had good quality Banh Mi for low, low prices (nothing more than $3). But now, since working in SF, I don't have that option. When I first discovered Saigon Sandwiches, I was like, okay, I have cheap Vietnamese options for lunch now. Not the best though and no where on the same level as Oakland's. 

My coworker then told me that DragonEats was the place to get Banh Mi and all others are crap, so I decided to try it. Got the 5-spiced Chicken Banh Mi. I have to say that the flavors are pretty much on key. The baguette was perfectly crisp and the chicken was juicy with a good aioli sauce. It's just the sticker shock that kills this experience. 

Will I stop coming back here? No, because it's the only option I have for good Banh Mi in SF. But it is no Banh Mi Ba Le or Cam Huong in Oakland.

Oh btw, I accidentally got the pork banh mi one time. Let me tell you...BIG MISTAKE! Stick with the 5-spiced chicken!
author: Henry P.

description: Dropped in to try the Bon mi Meatball sandwich an I wasn't disappointed. Great flavor. A little small & a little pricey but it's SF & the quality is really good. Can't wait to try their other dishes.
author: Herbert H.

description:
DragonEats great banh mi, amazing daily kale soup, delicious spring rolls, super fresh fast and friendly, what more could you want.  Good sized portions at a decent price for high quality.
Lemonade is one of the best out there.  Small & cozy with some outside seating.  It should definitely be checked out.
author: Portia S.

description:
Decent place to grab some quick Vietnamese food, I just wish the portions were a tad bigger!I've been spoiled by giant portions in Sac. 

They have a simple menu for bowl or banh mi. Good for a quick bite.
author: Luc L.

description: Found this place while on jury duty a few blocks away. Went there a couple times and it was just perfect.
author: Dmitry D.

description: If you're in Hayes Valley and need banh mi, this is your only option. Lucky for you, it is a good option! Tasty sandwiches made quickly! Prices are about 65% higher than Saigon Sandwich. But in this "affluent neighborhood" a $7 lunch is about as cost-effective as you're apt to find. I hope DragonEats expands their hours, as they close at 6pm or earlier daily.
author: Abe A.

description:
Not consistent. The first time I got the duck bahn mi the duck was falling out of the bread and was so good. Today I got the duck and it's like 3 pieces of duck and so flat it's like there was nothing in there. 

The prices are also inconsistent with their website.
author: Flip T.

description: The best banh mi in San Francisco. I like to think i know what a good sandwich is. Their sandwiches are layered and the bread is toasted just right! Pork meatball is my favorite! The staff is friendly and nice. Wish they opened until later though.
author: Satyam D.

description: Delicious, fast and cheap.  We ordered both of the chicken banh my, togo, tho we would have been happy to stay if we had the time.  Cute little dive, pleasant staff, and great value. $7 for each sandwich (okay, banh my), the french bread was among the best I've had, the veggies crisp and fresh, and the chicken beautifully seasoned. We will definitely return.  Just steps from Davies Symphony Hall and the Performing Arts Parking Garage.
author: J A.

description: Had high expectations based on the other yelp reviews but ultimately was disappointed. The Bahn mi sandwiches are not that big especially considering the price. In addition both the roast pork and five spice chicken tasted quite dry. Better off going to Saigon sandwich
author: Cindy W.

description: First time here and first roast duck banh mi ever and it was seriously the best Vietnamese sandwich I've ever had.
author: Dan R.

description:
I tried this place yesterday and already recommended it to two strangers I shared my Lyft ride with. 

The roasted pork bahn mi I had was worth stepping outside of my diet plan. Juicy, delicious, outstanding and for just $6.50 it was the best lunch I could think of.
author: Anelya S.

description:
"hella good hella cheap"

Sardine banh mi - is an item on the menu, its also something you'd be hard pressed to find anywhere else. For the price of under $7 this is a great deal in the SOMA.

After the lunch rush the space is nice and not crowded - clearly best time to arrive.
author: Oleg H.

description: Portioned for ants. I asked for no veggies and extra noodles. As a business, I'd be embarrassed at how small their portions are. *see photo* (This is the 4th time this has happened, I think it's time to write them off) Better off grabbing a snickers bar to satisfy your hunger.
author: Yuxuan N.

description:
Cheap. Fresh. Delicious. 

Pork Banh Mi Sandwich:
Bread was crisp and toasty but not hard. Veggies were fresh and clean. Meat was soft and flavorful. Overall the best banh mi sandwich I have eaten in the past 5 years. You'll feel like a majestic... dragon while eating this meal! 

Thanks DragonEats!
author: Melissa L.

description:
Hole in the wall - a bright green sign with no words. Somewhat hipster with the decor and such, but a great place for banh mi's!

Tried the 5-spice chicken, and it was just delicious! Smaller portion for those comparing to a "standard" burrito - but super fresh vegetables (cilantro-heavy for those who are cilantro-averse), plenty of saucy chicken, and the bread is crispy and amazing!

Must-try for those in the area!
author: Greg G.

description: My hubby and I went to this place after getting happy hour drinks from Sugar Lounge and it hit the spot! He ordered the meatball sandwich and I ordered the 5 spice chicken sandwich and they both tasted fresh, flavorful, and delicious. Highly recommended.  Good prices for the given area.
author: Virginia F.

description: I'm giving 5STAR to this place. One of the affordable eateries in Hayes Valley. Delicious banh mi sandwiches & vermicelli bowls for around $7.
author: Mega Team R.

description:
Very good Banh Mi (this comes from a Vietnamese guy who loves eating Banh Mi all his life), the baguette is almost perfect, the pickle carrot and cucumber are fresh & excellent, the meat is very good. I had the 5 spice chicken and the pork. They include pate with both. Next time I want to try without the pate.  I think it will allow me to taste the meat better. The pate dominates the taste so much that I can't even tell the differences between the chicken and the pork.

Little pricey for a Vietnamese Banh Mi but I think it is worth it since the service is very good and they use quality ingredients.  Will come back.
author: Thien B.

description: OMG Banh Mi that makes me drool just thinking about it.  The bread is so soft that it soaks up all of the flavors.  It's a tiny space so it can get a bit crowded, but MMMM so worth it.
author: Greta R.

description:
Awesome little shop which serves Vietnamese sandwiches. 

Pro tip: 
They do tend to run out of Duck, so make sure you arrive earlier in the day. 

A little pricey for a sandwich, but what do you except, its San Francisco
author: Gaurav B.

description: Was craving a bahn mi sandwich and stumbled upon DragonEats. Not only do they serve bahn mi sandwiches, they have spring rolls, vermicelli bowls, etc. So, against my cravings, I decided to go with the Five Spice Chicken vermicelli bowl (a take on a bahn mi sandwich but switch out the bread with vermicelli noodles). And I have to say, I was more than happy with my change of mind because I can seriously eat this for lunch for the rest of my life. It had the perfect balance of flavors from the chicken and freshness from the various vegetables on top of the perfect amount of noodles with their sauce on the side and crispy shallots. It was super clean, left me comfortably full and very satisfied. I will come back to try their bahn mi sandwiches if I'm not tempted to change my mind again!
author: Debb M.

description:
Walked by, wasn't planning on eating - but it looks way too hole-in-the-wally with a modern twist for me NOT to step in. 

So, once I stepped in... the Vietnamese aroma totally got me. 
A Banh Mi shop in the Fillmore ish area? I dig it. 

I grabbed a sandwich, and also some spring rolls to go, which totaled to about $11. Pricey for a banh mi and spring rolls, but I wasn't surprised. 

It had an Asian fusion vibe, with an authentic taste. Literally. The food tasted amazing! I would definitely swing back and grab a bite to-go again. 

The food only took 5 mins to come out, and it was still pretty lively right before it closed (5pm - kinda early). Definitely family owned, which is a +! 

Yum!
author: Ben T.

description: Phenomenal. Limited menu, but oh so good and healthy. Love their bowls, especially. Chicken bowl is amazing and cheap.
author: N'olo J.

description: This is just for the bowls. It really should be called the cup. You open it up its half the bowl. There's only a few strands of vermicelli noodles. For $6.50 it is cheap. But it's also half the size of a normal vermicelli bowl. Flavors are good.
author: Sam S.

description: Pretty expensive for a Vietnamese sandwich but it's pretty good. I got the duck sandwich which was yummy. Service is fast. Small Lil spot so there's Not a lot of places to sit inside. Since it's in downtown sf, parking is horrible. Cash only!
author: Felicia S.

description: I'm addicted. Can't beat the price or speed. My favorite part is the crunch of the bread (without being too crummy everywhere).
author: Alice M.

description: I find this sandwich shop when I was walking around in this neighborhood. For banh my the Vietnamese sandwich beside chicken and pork, I was very interested on the roasted duck for the protein in the sandwich. When I got the sandwich I was quite disappointed on the portion as it is small but is understandable since this is San Francisco and the sandwich is only $7 (or $6.50 for other protein), but the quality of the sandwich didn't disappointed me because the herbs are fresh and the sliced roasted duck taste good and easy to chew. Beside the size I'm very satisfied. I also had a Vietnamese coffee and the coffee is good as there isn't a lot of condensed milk so is not too sweet and the coffee itself is bitter enough for the flavor.
author: Jacques S.

description: I get lunch here at least once a week.  The menu has options for meat and non-meat eaters. I believe there are even vegan sauce options if you ask. The soup (it is not written on menu board) is great on cold/rainy days. I do wish they offered paper cups instead of the plastic cups for the cucumber mint water. Also, it would be super if they used masking tape on the paper wrapping instead of the plastic tape.
author: Amy M.

description:
We were in the neighborhood for performing arts and yelp had many stars on this place.
Food was OK.  Quantity was small for the price.  But we need to keep in mind that we are not in Little Saigon.  
This could be called Fusion; after all, this is Hayes Valley. Rent is high.

Ginger chicken soup with kale for $3.  It was good, I liked it.
Shrimp papaya salad for $6.  The shrimp was fresh and cooked perfectly.  The sauce could use more kick.
Chicken noodle bowl for $6  It was also good but used to getting more.

The place is clean and bright.
The food was good, but had better.  
I think Asian would not appreciate this place because they are used to getting more and better food for same price.
author: Connie W.

description:
It wasn't bad, but it wasn't special either.  I'm just too spoiled by Larkin Street to get into the gentrified SF Vietnamese restaurants where you pay twice as much for the food, get half as much, but don't have anything upsetting in the vicinity.  

That said - I thought the food was a little better than average.  I've had the Banh Mi a couple of times - one with Pork, another with Duck.  The sandwich is pretty tasty - I thought the Duck was pretty good, and a nice change of pace from my typical Banh Mi choices.  But, here's the deal:  It's not a lot of food for the price ($6 - Cash Only), they could stand to put a few more veggies on the sandwich, and it's a little dry.  Yes - I won't see anyone who views the TL as the World's Largest Public Restroom roaming the streets.  But, double-for-half sits poorly with my mid-Western/Scandinavian cheap-skatedness.  

That said - it's clean, the service is fine, and the space is pretty nice.  The food feels healthy to me after eating it.  I do appreciate the floor to ceiling windows on a nice day.  I'm REALLY tempted to give this place four stars just for the free water with cucumber slices.  ... but, double-for-half...  Sigh.

Perfectly adequate if it's nearby.  Not worth going out of your way.
author: Adam S.

description: I love Dragoneats. Their sandwiches are great, and bowls  are even better. The place is always clean and the service is quick. The thai iced teas are hard to resist.
author: John P.

description:
So listen...girrrrlll....these sandwiches are everything. I came in from a long day of driving and getting errands done and the spirit told me to come here because I was going to get my life. So I listened to the lord....and I got my motherfu*king life!! 

I had the sardine bahn my, and it was amazing with Siraccha sauce


Definitely coming back here.
author: Rukayatu T.

description: A great Vietnamese restaurant in San Francisco! My husband and I were craving banh mi sandwiches and spring rolls, so we came to the right place. Everything was cooked very well and had tons of flavor. I opted for the tofu banh mi. The baguette was crispy, yet soft at the same time. My husband ordered the tofu rolls for us to share and the peanut sauce was delicious. Everything was relatively inexpensive for San Francisco's typical price point. It's a good stop for lunch or small dinner while you're exploring the city.
author: Nina M.

description:
Let me preface that this is not the most authentic Vietnamese food. This place is for hipsters. Nonetheless, the food here is very delicious. As a D6 native, I can tell you that yes, this place is cheap...but there are bahn mi places in D6 that are cheaper (and more "authentic") and just as tasty. E.g. Saigon Sandwich. 

++vegetarian option available (tofu)
++accepts credit cards
++try your best to keep the bahn mi horizontal to avoid spilling (or should I say losing) the amazing juices
author: Anna H.

description:
Eating in Hayes Valley can be expensive, so we really appreciate this little eatery that serves good Vietnamese street food.

We ordered papaya salad, chicken vermicelli, ginger chicken broth with noodles, spring rolls and banh mi with pork. $27 for a meal for 4 people! 

The food isn't spectacular, but it's not bad either. Nothing that jumps out as memorable, but we wouldn't mind coming back again for a solid and reasonable meal in our hood.
author: Dawne L.

description: I've been coming to DragonEats for years, and for the most part I've always had great experiences.  The food is always solid, and the people who work there are courteous and friendly. Unfortunately I've come to the point where I no longer feel like I can eat there. A year or so back they switched to disposable dishes and from what I can tell they make no effort to recycle or compost the staggering amount of waste that they create. It's truly insane how much garbage is created from ordering lunch for one.  It would be so easy to convert to reusable plates and utensils or at the very least make everything they use compostable. So bye for now DragonEats- until you reign in your wasteful ways.
author: Ryan S.

description:
During a weekday lunch hour, I had a choice between a bahnmi or a brown bag of two Turkey deli slices, cheese, and two slices of 5 day old seed bread. After deliberating for about 2 seconds, I picked Dragon.

It was my first time here so I had to order a bahnmi. Although the papaya salad looked pretty good too. Nice little store front on the fringes of Hayes Valley shopes, the takeout joint had a few community seats for you to sit and eat.

At first glance, the sandwich was smaller than I expected, but on closer inspection, the ingredients were packed more tightly together than at other joints. I had the chicken and it had good flavor, although the salt and other seasonings overcame the meat somewhat. The carrots and daikon and the other veggies were crispy and fresh. French roll tasted as if it baked that morning.

For a bahnmi it was really good. But I hit Little Saigon often and its hard to beat the value they offer over there. But this place is one of my top Vietnamese sandwich joints.
author: Kris P.

description: You had me at Duck Bahn Mi. It's not your traditional Bahn Mi, however they understand when you say extra jalapenos and they don't give you a bottle of Sriracha to pour in a plastic bag for "to go" (although, it is pretty charming at my favorite Bahn Mi place). If you're in the neighborhood, try it out. There's also a sweet little bar around the corner you can take it to and have a beer or Fernet.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Pretty solid banh mi, but it was a bit on the overfilled/mushy side for me. Their 5 spice chicken is excellent. The banh mi includes pate and an umami mayo. These are usually pretty good together, but everything in the sandwich was really wet. Pate was wet, too much mayo, and maybe the juice from the chicken. And they seemed to remove some of the white part of the otherwise great bread to pack more stuff in. So the sandwich got really soggy, and was kind of a mayo-y mess by the end. 

I also got the papaya salad, which had a lot of fresh ingredients, but weirdly not that much papaya.
author: Adam W.

description: Amazing value meal in Hayes Valley and possibly one of the best banh mi's I've had in SF (so far!)
author: Paolo V.

description: Duck Banh Mi is incredible 10/10 I had it for lunch and wanted to go back for dinner. It was amazing.
author: Jenny L.

description:
I'm completely addicted to the 5-spice chicken bahn mi.
I have literally bought a sandwich for immediate consumption, and another for later; if I *really* love something, I can eat it everyday and not get tired of it. There's not many things I *really* love, though. This is one.
author: Eric V.

description: The best kale and ginger broth soup! And the shrimp roles are so fresh. 4 stars instead of 5 because I was nonplussed by the fresh chicken rolls.
author: Erin W.

description: Twon, the owner, provides a consistently delicious lunch for a great price. He's also a very personal guy and fun to talk with! I can't recommend this place enough.
author: Max B.

description: Excellent pork sandwich, pretty good shrimp roll but only one piece of shrimp.
author: Alison D.

description: I've had this a few times since my last review, and it's way better - think I originally had a one off experience. The rolls have been fresh, and the five spice chicken bowl is really yummy. Great fresh meal to take home if you're in the area!
author: Sarah B.

description:
Much better Vietnamese food can be found in the city. 

The search for a good lunch spot near my internship continues. Came a little after 12:30 and the place was packed! If you are looking to sit down for your lunch break, this may not be the place--there are only two or three tables, and extremely limited counter seating. The menu and photos looked promising, and I ordered a five spice chicken fresh bowl. To their credit, the ingredients were very fresh. But, the chicken was surprisingly bland. The fish sauce was also not as flavorful (huh?! how is that even possible?) Banh mi is $6 a pop, which seems a little exorbitant. The bowls are the same price and more reasonably priced, in my opinion. This place seems to be more Americanized Vietnamese, and with the great places in the sunset/TL (and across the bridge in Oakland) this place fell short on my list.
author: Angela L.

description: $6.50 for 2 shrimp rolls.  Really tasty with the peanut sauce and healthy, but it is a bit expensive compared to other places that sells vietnamese rolls.  However, it is in Hayes Valley, so it's considered fairly cheap around the area.
author: Karen L.

description:
The cash register guy was super nice.

I got the Pork Fresh Bowl. It was good, the noodles at the bottom were so tasty and their  texture was perfect. I would have liked more noodles, but everything in the bowl was good. the middle was mostly fresh green stuff and lots of cilantro. The pork was good too, well seasoned and mostly moist and not too fatty. It came with a little tub of sauce, I think it was fish sauce and I didn't really feel like having that at the time; it had plenty of good flavor without it and I was happy.

My girlfriend got the a Shrimp Fresh Bowl, she said she liked it a lot for many of the same reasons I liked mine. She used the fish sauce and liked it.

We both got the Vietnamese Iced Coffee, and neither of us liked it. It had a bad aftertaste. I thought it left a sort of sweet liquor aftertaste, she thought it tasted medicinal. I get what she means, it has a sort of herby aftertaste. I won't get the coffee again. 

I'd go back if I am in the area and looking for a good fast and fresh lunch.
author: Jeremy B.

description: I was hesitant about this place at first -- banh mi that costs slightly more than usual -- but I grew to like it a lot and I've tried just about everything here now. Both the shrimp and tofu fresh rolls are delish. The Vietnamese coffee is made strong. The soup of the day is usually a clear broth with some kind of greens, think hot kale water. The duck sandwich is the best item on the menu I think. The pork meatball runs a close second. There are two types of chicken -- butter chicken and 5 spice chicken. I recommend the 5 spice and pass on the butter. With the sandwiches, you can choose from the entire protein line-up. But with the bowls, you only get pork, chicken, or tofu. The bowls are lighter on the noodle and heavier on the greens. I suggest putting an order ahead of time.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Date & Time:  Wednesday July 18, 2012 @ Noon
Dining Companion:  The Husband
Scene:  Hayes Valley Peeps in Fedoras, Ray Bans & "I Party with Jay Gatsby" Sweat Shirts
Decor:  Urban Postage-Sized Stamp Eatery w/ Asian Influences.  Counter-Seating & Communal Table
Service:  Nice Guy
Imbibe:  Vietnamese Iced Coffee & Lemonade with Jellies
Devour:  Vietnamese Street Food:  Shrimp Imperial Rolls, Ham Banh Mi, 5-Spiced Chicken Fresh Noodles.  Organic Ingredients.  Flan Coming Soon
Total:  $26.05
Note:  Closes when Food Runs-Out Usually Between 2pm-3pm
author: Genevieve Y.

description: Great Vietnamese a low price. Bowls, sandwiches, and rolls. Homemade lemonade was exceptional as well. For a quick bite in Hayes Valley, this tops my list for sure. I will be returning very soon!!
author: Andrew G.

description: I love this place!  Fair price, tasty banh mi's, and super fast.  My only gripe: they never pick up the phone when you want to phone in an order.
author: Jen M.

description:
This place hit the spot today. 
So I yelped "cheap food" that were located around work today, and I'm really happy I found this place!

It's pretty small but it's really clean and cute and I appreciate the simplicity of their menu. The workers were also really nice and willing to answer questions. I got the teriyaki tofu fresh bowl and a 5 spice chicken banh mi for later; the fresh bowl was bomb though. Super flavorful and light, which is good for a work day lunch. The service was also HELLA fast, another plus for anyone in a rush. 

The only thing I didn't like was that my sandwich was kinda dry and the bread wasn't as soft as I like it to be. But, i will definitely be back for more :)
author: Maurelle B.

description: Excellent bowls, rolls and iced coffee. Very reasonable prices for the city. Fast, healthy and really good. Love that this is close by.
author: Megan M.

description:
I'm addicted to bahn mi, so much so that I once considered getting it for 8€ in the Milan train station. Just for the flavor, that sweet, sensual tang and healthy zest of fresh, robust veggies.

Yes, I said "sensual."

DragonEats is the happy medium between cheap (Saigon Sandwiches) and overpriced (Bun Mee). Service is friendly and they have a rockin' salad for when you want to go lighter.

Yes, I said "rockin'."

$6 for most items on the menu with no need for add-ons. You and your wallet will leave satisfied.
author: Keane L.

description:
Love this place - a local favorite! Very affordable (roughly $6.50 per item) and always tastes fresh. Recommend: Shrimp Fresh Rolls (peanut sauce is delish!) or pork bahn mi (tip: ask for extra house pickled vegetables - you won't regret it). 

Con: sometimes at lunch  it can get busy (to be expected) but they can also get a bit careless with orders (aka always check you have your peanut sauce). I'd say that forgetting part of an order is rare and a growing pain as they expand operations.
author: Kim M.

description: Most of you SF'ers need to realize authentic banh mi's are not supposed to cost $7, especially at this small of a sandwich size. They are $3 in SJ/Milpitas/Fremont and much bigger/filling. However I recognize that this is considered affordable in the neighborhood. I decided to try this place out since my friends wanted to come and it seemed to have a lot of good reviews. The sandwich itself was nothing like I've ever seen. It was wet from grease/sauce and fell apart in my hand and dripped everywhere. Banh mi's are supposed to be DRY and flaky ya'll. I left bewildered at why people rave about this place for having *cheap and genuine* Vietnamese food. Wake up people!
author: Jamie C.

description: I had shrimp fresh roll and chicken broth soup. The soup was amazingly good, has lots of layers. Very tasty. The fresh roll is very fresh, with lots of shrimp!
author: Ihsuan Y.

description:
I was in the neighborhood and was starving, so I decided to check yelp and see what was nearby and fast. I'm so happy it led me to DragonEats. I came with my mom and since we were quite hungry, we ordered a good portion of the menu.

We got shrimp spring rolls, 5 spice chicken bahn mi and a shrimp cabbage salad. All the food was extremely fresh and delicious. I found the salad a bit small but the rolls were quite large on the contrary. The bahn mi sandwich was BY FAR the highlight of my meal. I also ordered a delicious Vietnamese iced coffee- definitely recommend it. 

This place was also really cheap. They are unfortunately cash only- so make sure to visit an ATM ahead of time.
author: Natasha F.

description:
So glad I came across this spot near my work because I come here for lunch at least once a week now!

Don't be turned off by the long line - it moves pretty quickly. Some favorites are: Pork Meatball Banh My (so juicy), Tofu Fresh Bowl (favorite item on the menu), and Shrimp Fresh Roll (love the mint!).

Staff is always smiling and friendly, service is quick, and price is affordable. Thanks for existing DragonEats!
author: Megan K.

description: I've been wanting to check out this place and finally did and boy was I glad I did.  The pork sandwich is DEEELICIOUS!! The meat is is not overcooked and the seasoning is spot on.  This has since become our spot for when I am waiting on my stepdaughter to finish up her ballet class.
author: Kathy C.

description: Really solid basic options. Very reasonably priced for the area. The pork bahn mi was solid! Good bread, sauce and fresh veg. Really great!
author: David L.

description: Delicious bahn mi's in Hayes Valley. Pretty quick service and plenty of seats. Cucumber water is a nice touch. Love the duck bahn mi here. Other options looked really good as well!
author: Sherry L.

description: This place is awesome - cheap, delicious fresh Vietnamese food made to order. I usually get the rice paper spring rolls w peanut butter dipping sauce or the fresh roll with teriyaki tofu. He meat, seafood and all ingredients used are fresh and high quality. The value just can't be beat in this city!
author: Laurence S.

description:
I come here at least once a week and have tried almost everything on their menu so thought I should give it some love on Yelp.

Not going to make this super long, it seems that everyone else on Yelp agrees with me. DragonEats is awesome: their spring rolls, bahn mi, noodle bowls, and salads are all amazing. It's all homemade, and the meat options are all amazing (although the tofu's my favorite). Depending on the time, there can definitely be a line but it always moves quickly enough to where you can be in and out in less than 10 or 15 minutes. My one complaint would probably be that their (amazing) Vietnamese iced coffee is at least 50% ice which was confirmed by the one time my friend tried to order an iced coffee with no ice and was given a pathetically half full cup, but I think that's pretty standard and it shouldn't dissuade you from coming here.

DragonEats is bomb. And for Hayes Valley, the prices are crazy low. I really can't ask for much more.
author: Audrey S.

description:
3.5 stars but rounding down. I came here as part of the Gourmet Walks Hayes Valley Food Tour, and we got to try half of a Roasted Pork Banh Mi, which was surprisingly good! The bread was nice and toasty, and I liked their pickled vegetables and mayo. Although the pork was flavorful, this wasn't one of the top banh mis I've had. I do regret not trying the duck, which I think was a daily special- my coworkers that tried the duck were raving about it. 

This is a pretty small place, but there are tables and chairs to sit at inside. Overall, I would come back again to try additional banh mis from here.
author: Amy D.

description:
hip banh mi place.

i'm a fan.  it was good and i think i like this place better than dinosaur.  

i hope this place doesnt become overpriced.  thanks for keeping it real! i'll be back.
author: J. T.

description: I don't yelp... but I had the meatball Banh Mi today and it blew my mind, it was SO GOOD!
author: T D.

description: Good product, s**t service. Small menu with decent prices. Good if you are rushing through lunch. Limited seating and only offers take out.
author: Yoshi V.

description: Pretty standard Banh Mis and vermicelli bowls, but for $6 you really can't complain.  Fresh ingredients and quick service.  Nice counter to snack at, too.
author: Malachi Z.

description: I like this spot a lot. And if I worked in the area I'd be here several times a week. It's simple, easy, quick, and cute. Authentic without the overbearing ambience of a traditional Vietnamese spot. I had the five spice chicken fresh bowl, which is basically your traditional bun bowl. Lots of fresh veggies and I didn't actually find the vermicelli noodles until almost finishing it because there were so many veggies...I like that though, makes it lighter. The fish sauce is of good quality also, not too smelly. Fresh rolls were good too, a little more expensive than most places but if the quality is good I'm willing to pay extra. Next time I'd get a fresh bowl and a side of soup for $3...hopefully it's a pho-like broth! They are obviously famous for their bahn mi which regrettably I didn't get, but really want to try next time.
author: Rosie I.

description:
Had a papaya salad with shrimp. It was alright, nothing I would go back for again.. It was only $6.51 with tax so that was a plus for cheap lunch! Wish I would of got the spring rolls instead, seems like more people order those and they come in a pack of two so it would be a nice lunch for the same price. 

The store sign is small so you won't see if from down the block. 

The inside was small but nice, clean.. Some seating for dine.

Register counter is next to the kitchen so you can see in, really teeny tiny kitchen!
author: Katrina M.

description:
You got me hooked, and I'm going to miss you when I return to Los Angeles.

Flavor. Freshness. Filling. Fuckin' delicious.

A hit on the first try, I got in nice and early, only a couple folks hanging about and more filtering in while I chowed down.

A simple house made lemonade to pair up with my pork banh mi, and I was in a nice chill heaven as my brows began to sweat from my walk and the jalapeno -- a nice spicy few slices.

I was checked up on during my meal, and let them know that I loved the sandwich, and they were genuinely appreciative of my feedback. Seriously delicious, and a decent price to boot. There's no lack of anything going on in that banh mi and the pork is SO good.

I'm coming back, and you should go, too.

Really, now. Go on.

Try it.
author: Cate T.

description:
My friend and I shared the roasted duck and roasted pork banh mis and enjoyed both! The meat in both sandwiches was tender and flavorful, and all the fresh garnishes cut the fat nicely. At $6 each, they were a relatively cheap and satisfying meal. 

While eating our sandwiches, we noticed everyone who came in after us ordered the bowl, so I'll definitely be back to try that!
author: Abby S.

description: Love this small eatery in Hayes Valley. Always super fast service, even at busiest lunch times, and everything is fresh and delicious. I recommend the five spice chicken Banh Mi. Great place to grab a sandwich for a quick lunch!
author: Monica M.

description: Came here during my lunch break based on the reviews. Sandwich options are different vs the traditional banh mi places. I got the roast duck banh mi. The sandwich was tasty. Wish it were a normal size... About half the size of a traditional banh mi. It was a bit greasy, but it's duck fat. So it was tasty grease. It's also 3x's the price of a normal banh mi. Overall, glad I tried it, but probably wouldn't go back.
author: LIVE to E.

description:
Dragoneats Vietnamese street food keeps it simple, fresh and affordable. You can get a bowl, banh mi or fresh rolls for $6. Choose your protein: pork, chicken, tofu skin or sardine. 

* Pork banh mi ($6): The pork isn't the typical roast pork or BBQ pork that you usually find in banh mi. They use big pieces of marinated pork belly. The pork is nice (better quality than usual); it's a little sweet with a touch of soy. The carrots were sweet and barely pickled. There was one sliver of daikon. The sandwich included cucumber, cilantro (including the stems), jalapeno, mayo and a thin smear of pate. The toasted roll from Bakers of Paris was firm and chewy. I liked the meat and bread but the carrots need improvement. 
* Lemonade: housemade drink was too sweet and too warm

It's a small place with mismatched furniture and cheerful blue walls. There's limited seating inside and a few chairs outside.

Cash only.
author: Lolia S.

description:
Maybe the cheapest lunch in the city, but the price makes no compromise in deliciousness.  Super quick,  comfortable seating,  in and out and only regret is I didn't grab another to go! 

Got the pork meatball Bahn My,  three words: moist  big balls.  One of the better Bahn Mys that I have had. 

Boyfriend had fresh bowl with roasted pork which was layered with lettuce noodles meat and vinegar fish sauce dressing.  No complaints.
author: Oliver B.

description:
Food was good. I had the fresh bowl. 
FYI - it's cash only and the people who work here don't smile. 

Otherwise it was good. I wouldn't go back though.
author: Sara P.

description: Good and fresh sandwiches. I have only tried the 5-spices chicken sandwich, but have had it a half dozen times. Consistently hot and fresh with a generous portion of meat and veggies. Make sure to add jalapeños
author: Omar A.

description: Solid Vietnamese sandwiches, and not pricy at all! Really busy in weekends though. Not sure if they have plug outlets.
author: B H.

description:
This is a little place that is mostly communal seating.  Bahn My is an easy grab and go sandwich if you you are short on time:-)

Had chicken Bahn My sandwich.  It is a fusion and not true Vietnamese style. Great sauce!  Little bit of heat.  $6 each.

My team mate had the shrimp spring rolls and said they were really good.

I would definitely come back here!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
This place has your typical fast food Vietnamese fare. The bread is a little bit too hard and the meat maybe just a bit too mushy. Despite that, it's a great joint if you're looking for cheap and decent food. 

On the plus side, spiciness on food is tastefully done.
author: Ryuta O.

description: It's hard to find bad food in Hayes valley and this restaurant is no different. Everything on the menu is fresh and delicious. I am personally very fond of the pork bahn mi but everything looks good here. Also very affordable considering its in the heart of sf.
author: Emily P.

description: Really authentic, inexpensive(for the bay) Bahn Mi's. I love eating there, and the food is always on point!
author: Beth C.

description: The best lunch deal in Hayes Valley! I enjoy everything especially their spring rolls that have avocado inside. Probably not the most authentic spot, but who cares. The employee at the register is always friendly. Food comes our fast and everything tastes fresh. I also appreciate their free cucumber water!
author: David D.

description: Great salad bowl not that much of the serving but it's good. Small place but still pleasant
author: James D.

description: Sorry, but the flavor of DragonEat's food doesn't compare to many other Vietnamese places I frequent. Is the food decent? Yes, it's fine. But it doesn't have that extra pop of flavor that I crave when eating Vietnamese sandwiches. It is also way more expensive. So in summary, I would go here if I was desperate and in the area, but if I'm craving delicious Vietnamese food, I'll go elsewhere.
author: John L.

description:
As as East Coast chic I am living this city! 
I ordered the noodle bowl with chicken and the spring rolls along wit the fresh lemon aide.
  Service was fast and very nice. Smiling dare I say flirting with me. The noodle bowl has lots of fresh spices mint , parsley tiny potato  chip rounds for some crunch and nice fresh sprouts. Spring rolls were lovely fresh and tasty with  nice sized shrimp and peanut dipping sauce.
  Takes only cash!
author: Megan M.

description:
Bowls, shrimp rolls and a Bahn Mi! Our favorite lunch spot when it's cold outside.
Super tasty.
author: Unkl- T.

description:
After paying toll, using half your tank of gas to fight inner-city traffic and using the other half of your tank to find parking, and finally paying for the meter - my wallet was a little sad. But my wallet (and my stomach) cheered up quite a bit when we found this little gem. Also there was this little Border Collie that passed by us as we were parking that was wearing goggles. That helped cheer me up too. 

Tucked away in Hayes Valley, this delightful spot was home to some very tasty and very affordable sandwiches. Can you tell where my priorities are at? But seriously, it was only $6 for a well-sized sandwich. And though I know Banh mi can be even more affordable - when you're in the city this was quite a deal. And the Garlic Butter Chicken Sandwich was absolutely delicious.

And yes, I know I should take the MUNI. But I promise I was coming from far out of the city, ok! Gimme a break!
author: Paul Z.

description:
Viet'YEAH!  It's cheap, it's fast, and it's in your face!  For the opera or symphony crowd, this is pretty much the perfect pre-concert mess hall.  Just kidding, it's anything but a hall.  So small in fact, that even cats would find this place claustrophobic.  But despite the size, their Bánh mì and fresh bowls satisfy even the largest guts.  I'm addicted to their five spice dishes (both the Bánh mì and the bowl).   Their website sucks but it doesn't matter, instead just pay attention to the paper menu at the restaurant.  

Fun things to try:  1. Dodge the cigarette projectiles that the bearded mentally ill homeless person throws at you while standing outside.  2. Ask for the bathroom key then get sent outside and down the hall to a fairly clean handicapped accessible restroom.  3. There is only one bicycle rack outside on the street, so wait for a good-looking guy or gal to pull up and offer to double-lock your bicycle with them.  (SCORE!)
author: Daniel C.

description:
This place is perfect! Everything (sandwiches, bowls, salads) is just $6. All of the food is just the right serving size: will leave you full, but not hating yourself from eating too much. The food is fresh, as is the delicious limeade ($3). We tried a couple of different things, and the pork banh mi was my favorite.

The inside is not big, but very clean and looks newly designed. You order at the counter, and everyone I saw who worked here was really cheery.  If I lived or worked nearby I would be here all the time!
author: Vivek K.

description: Got a 5 spice chicken bowl and it was SO GOOD. These guys are doing it right!!! 5 stars for taste and prices.
author: Erika Janelle O.

description: Amazing, clean, hole in the wall for great bahn mi's, noodle bowls or fresh salads. Seats about 20 people and it gets busy for lunch. However, the service is wicked fast. I must have been there for like 20-30 minutes and they had served a good 30-40 people in that short time. We had the garlic butter chicken bahn mi and tofu bahn mi, both were amazing - fresh ingredients, flavor not-chewy chicken and tofu. Will definitely try the noodle bowls next time.
author: Sia P.

description: They have the best fresh spring rolls in San Francisco. Good for takeout and dine-in.
author: Jessica Z.

description:
I work near Hayes Valley but don't usually wander around Gough Street. I saw DragonEats and noticed the cute decor so my co-worker and I came in for a bite. Very cute decor, part industrial but has an homage to Vietnam and also to the French Fusion (i.e. cafe du mond coffee as decorations)

I ordered the papaya shrimp salad and it was great! Staff is also really nice. Open kitchen concept.

My co-worker really enjoyed his duck banh mi too.

This is probably the cleanest Vietnamese restaurant I have ever been in!

Prices are a bit higher of course from the sandwich shops in the TL as a result.
author: Betty C.

description:
This is a pretty good spot to grab lunch. I've been here twice and tried the duck banh mi, pork fresh (noodle) bowl, and the spring rolls. All were definitely to my liking. However, I do have one dislike, the fresh bowl's portion is wayyyy too little for its price!! It's pretty refreshing and delicious! But the portion is too little, such a tease! Other than that, the duck banh mi was yummy! They have the actual chinese style roasted duck meat in the sandwich, never seen that anywhere! Definitely unique! And the spring rolls were good, the sauce is pretty legit. 

Would I go again? Probably, but I'm most likely not gonna get the fresh noodle bowl. Too little to satisfy my hunger needs ;P lol it's good tho, don't get me wrong.
author: Cindy C.

description:
DO YOURSELF A FAVOR: JUST GO TO THE TL. THE END. 

As much as I would love to leave it at that, I hate one-liner reviews. I wouldn't be much of a helpful Yelper if I left it at that now, would I?

After seeing Genevieve Y.'s review yesterday (congrats on the FTR!), I was excited to learn that DragonEats opened in Hayes Valley near my office. I'm "attempting" to eat healthier these days and saw that they had brown rice on the menu which is the ONLY reason why I decided to not pack my lunch today and go to DragonEats.  

DragonEats' concept is Vietnamese street food with 2 Spring Roll, 5 Banh Mi (they call it Banh My) and 4 Noodle/Brown Rice Bowl options on the menu. They claim all their ingredients are organic (not sure about that as I felt MSG aftereffects). Everything is $6. 

Again, the only reason why I came here was because they have brown rice on the menu. When ordering, I was told the brown rice wasn't ready. When I inquired how long it would take, they later said, they wouldn't have brown rice at all today. Umm, please take it off the chalkboard menu for today then because the 2 customers after me were also asking for brown rice (one ended up leaving).

I didn't just walk 10 minutes for nothing so I ordered the Tofu Banh My ($6) and the Five-Spice Chicken Noodle Bowl ($6); half of each for lunch and the rest for dinner later. 

The Tofu Banh My was TERRIBLE! You would think a Tofu Banh Mi would be a healthy option but it was NOT. The baguette roll was oily and left grease stains on the white wrapper while the scant tofu filling was incredibly bland. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ziWibyZYvqtrbc7f9v2iPg?select=JyP_z2W_pJzYLu0AB6ITjg#Ub8DXwH1hb41BmhSOqjWnA There was no Maggi sauce and no pickled veggies or jalapenos, things an authentic banh mi should have. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ziWibyZYvqtrbc7f9v2iPg?select=JyP_z2W_pJzYLu0AB6ITjg#sjg9vYlwBkrpt7TObzTS1Q And for $6 (a Banh Mi is normally $3-$4)? RIPOFF. Several bites left me feeling gross so I proceeded to eating the Five-Spiced Chicken and Veggies. The chicken was cold and had no char/grill marks as it should. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ziWibyZYvqtrbc7f9v2iPg?select=JyP_z2W_pJzYLu0AB6ITjg#yy4LrKz2jfixXt9bWo3Qiw Trying to abstain from as much refined carbs as I can, I didn't touch the rice noodles but I couldn't help but noticed how small the portion was compared to traditional Vietnamese restaurants.  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ziWibyZYvqtrbc7f9v2iPg?select=JyP_z2W_pJzYLu0AB6ITjg#zG3krzTF4K6KEl_OvB1HFw
 
Next time, I'll take the extra 5 minutes to walk to the TL and step over crackheads to get authentic Vietnamese food at a fraction of the cost. 

Best of luck, DragonEats...seriously.

OTHER NOTES:
*Open Monday - Friday 11 AM - 3 PM
*Very cute décor with vibrant blues and greens
*Communal table seating for 5 and counter seating for 6
*Everything served in to-go containers
*CASH ONLY
author: Cherylynn N.

description: For what I got I thought it was overpriced. Most Vietnamese restaurants give you huge portions for the same price I got a smallish/medium take out bowl, whether you ask for it to-go or not.
